title: Cloud Lock-in Gradient
context: Engineering teams adopt managed cloud services to move faster. The first service is a pragmatic choice — why build a message queue when SQS exists? Then comes DynamoDB because it integrates neatly. Then Lambda because it's serverless. Then Step Functions for orchestration. Each decision is locally rational. But the cumulative effect is a system so deeply coupled to one provider that migration becomes a multi-year, multi-million dollar project. The lock-in doesn't happen in one decision — it's a gradient, each step making the next proprietary choice easier and the exit harder.
hypothesis: Using managed cloud services saves engineering time without creating meaningful lock-in.

effects.label: Each proprietary service makes the next one easier to justify

children.label: IAM, networking, and monitoring deeply coupled to provider
Engineers develop provider-specific skills, reducing portability

effects.label: Switching costs compound non-linearly
effects.impact: Migration cost doubles with each year of adoption

children.label: Data gravity — terabytes of data in proprietary formats
Egress fees designed to make leaving expensive
No portable equivalent for many managed services

effects.label: Provider gains pricing leverage
effects.impact: Annual price increases of 5-15% become non-negotiable

children.label: Contract negotiations become one-sided — you have no credible exit threat
Reserved instance commitments lock in spend for 1-3 years

effects.label: Innovation constrained to provider's roadmap
effects.impact: Architecture limited by what provider offers

children.label: Can't adopt better tools if they don't exist in your provider's ecosystem
Provider deprecations force unplanned migrations within their ecosystem

dontIf: You're building a product where provider independence is a competitive requirement
Your cloud spend already exceeds 15% of revenue and is growing faster
ifYouMust: Use portable abstractions (Kubernetes, Terraform, PostgreSQL) for core infrastructure
Limit proprietary services to non-critical, easily replaceable components
Maintain a cloud exit plan document — update it quarterly
Negotiate egress fee waivers and price caps in multi-year contracts

alternatives.name: Cloud-agnostic stack
alternatives.note: Kubernetes + Terraform + open-source databases — portable by design

alternatives.name: Selective proprietary adoption
alternatives.note: Use managed services only where the time savings clearly outweigh the lock-in cost

alternatives.name: Multi-cloud for critical services
alternatives.note: Run core workloads on two providers — higher complexity but real negotiating leverage

sources.title: Andreessen Horowitz: The Cost of Cloud
sources.note: Cloud costs consume 50%+ of revenue for many SaaS companies, repatriation could save 30-50%

sources.title: Flexera State of the Cloud Report 2024
sources.note: Cloud waste estimated at 28% of total spend, vendor lock-in cited as top concern

sources.title: Gartner: Cloud Lock-in Risk Assessment
sources.note: 60% of enterprises identify single-cloud dependency as a top-5 technology risk

sources.title: 37signals: Why We're Leaving the Cloud
sources.note: 37signals saved $7M over 5 years by repatriating from AWS — only possible because they limited lock-in

falsifiability: Organizations using 20+ proprietary cloud services can migrate to another provider in under 6 months
Cloud provider pricing remains stable or decreases for locked-in customers over 5-year periods
Managed service adoption does not correlate with reduced negotiating leverage in contract renewals

seo.description: Cloud lock-in is a gradient, not a cliff. Each managed service makes the next easier to adopt and exit harder. Migration costs double annually, reaching $5-50M within 3 years.
